claim: Some birds have become fluent in English.

supporting.text: Birds lack the anatomical structures required for human speech production, such as vocal cords and a larynx capable of producing complex phonemes.

attacks.text: Birds lack the anatomical structures required for human speech production, such as vocal cords and a larynx capable of producing complex phonemes.
Some birds, like parrots, can mimic human speech with remarkable accuracy despite lacking identical anatomical structures.
Mimicry is not the same as fluency; parrots reproduce sounds without understanding or generating original speech.
Recent studies suggest certain parrots demonstrate contextual understanding of some words they mimic, indicating partial linguistic comprehension.

supporting.text: No scientific evidence or documented cases exist of birds achieving fluency in any human language, including English.

attacks.text: No scientific evidence or documented cases exist of birds achieving fluency in any human language, including English.
Some parrots, like Alex the African Grey, have demonstrated advanced linguistic capabilities, including syntax comprehension and contextual word use.
While parrots can mimic and contextualize words, their abilities fall short of true linguistic fluency, which requires generative grammar and abstract reasoning.
Anecdotal reports and viral videos occasionally claim birds exhibit fluent English, though these lack scientific verification.
Unverified anecdotes are insufficient to override the scientific consensus on avian cognitive limits in language acquisition.

supporting.text: Birds such as parrots can mimic human speech sounds but do not demonstrate comprehension or grammatical use of language.

attacks.text: Birds such as parrots can mimic human speech sounds but do not demonstrate comprehension or grammatical use of language.
Some parrots, like Alex the African Grey, have shown the ability to associate words with meanings and form simple sentences.
Alex's abilities were limited to trained responses and lacked true linguistic creativity or syntax understanding.
Mimicry alone does not equate to language fluency, as it lacks intentional communication or abstract thought.
Studies suggest some parrots use mimicry contextually, indicating rudimentary understanding of word usage.

supporting.text: Fluency in a language requires syntactic and semantic understanding, which has not been observed in any bird species.

attacks.text: Fluency in a language requires syntactic and semantic understanding, which has not been observed in any bird species.
Some birds, like parrots, can mimic human speech with contextual accuracy, suggesting a rudimentary form of semantic understanding.
Mimicry does not equate to fluency; parrots lack syntactic comprehension and cannot form novel sentences.
Studies on African grey parrots show they can associate words with meanings and use them appropriately in context.
Even if some birds demonstrate word-meaning associations, this falls short of the grammatical complexity required for true fluency.
